groups.name: cfpatterns
groups.description: The original 20 Workflow Control-Flow patterns from van der Aalst et al.

groups.name: cfpatterns
groups.description: The original 20 Workflow Control-Flow patterns from van der Aalst et al.

groups.name: errors
groups.description: Faulty processes which should be detected upon deployment.

constructs.name: InvalidLoopConditions
constructs.description: Checking the detection of invalid loop conditions.

constructs.name: ParallelGateway_Conditions
constructs.description: Checking the detection of invalid conditions attached to parallel gateways.

constructs.name: InvalidGatewayCombinations
constructs.description: Checking the detection of invalid combinations of gateway types resulting, e.g., resulting in deadlocks.

constructs.name: InvalidTokenQuantity
constructs.description: Checking the detection of invalid token quantities.

groups.name: data
groups.description: Model data flow within a process.

constructs.name: Property
constructs.description: Properties are item-aware elements not visually displayed on a Process diagram. (see BPMN spec pp.208-209)

constructs.name: DataObject
constructs.description: DataObjects are item-aware elements visually displayed on a Process diagram. (see BPMN spec pp.204-205)

groups.name: basics
groups.description: The basic building blocks of BPMN.

constructs.name: Participant
constructs.description: A Participant, depicted as a Pool in a BPMN diagram, represents a specific PartnerEntity (e.g., a company) and/or a more general PartnerRole (e.g., a buyer, seller, or manufacturer) that are participating in a Collaboration (see BPMN spec, p.113).

constructs.name: Lanes
constructs.description: A Lane is a sub-partition within a Process to organize and categorize Activities.

constructs.name: SequenceFlow
constructs.description: A SequenceFlow is used to define the order between elements in a Process.

constructs.name: SequenceFlow_Conditional
constructs.description: A conditional SequenceFlow is a SequenceFlow with an affixed condition.

groups.name: gateways
groups.description: Gateways control the routing behavior of a process.

constructs.name: ExclusiveGateway
constructs.description: A diverging Exclusive Gateway (Decision) is used to create alternative paths within a Process flow. A converging Exclusive Gateway is used to merge alternative paths. (see BPMN spec pp.289-291)

constructs.name: ComplexGateway
constructs.description: The Complex Gateway can be used to model complex synchronization behavior not covered by other gateway types (see BPMN spec pp.294-296)

constructs.name: InclusiveGateway
constructs.description: A diverging Inclusive Gateway (Inclusive Decision) can be used to create alternative but also parallel paths within a Process flow. A converging Inclusive Gateway is used to merge a combination of alternative and parallel paths. (see BPMN spec pp.291-292)

constructs.name: EventBasedGateway
constructs.description: The Event-Based Gateway represents a branching point in the Process where the alternative paths that follow the Gateway are based on Events that occur, rather than the evaluation of Expressions using Process data. (see BPMN spec pp.296-299)

constructs.name: MixedGatewayCombinations
constructs.description: Testing combinations of different gateway types.

constructs.name: ParallelGateway
constructs.description: A Parallel Gateway is used to synchronize (combine) parallel flows and to create parallel flows. (see BPMN spec pp.292-294)

groups.name: events
groups.description: Events make the BPMN process reactive, triggering start, end and intermediate events such as timers or messages.

constructs.name: Timer_Event
constructs.description: Timer Events are used if the event should be triggered by a Timer. (see BPMN spec p.273)

constructs.name: Error_Event
constructs.description: Error Events are used if the event should be triggered by an error. (see BPMN spec pp.264-265)

constructs.name: Message_Event
constructs.description: Message Events are used if the event should be triggered by a message. (see BPMN spec pp.269-270)

constructs.name: Conditional_Event
constructs.description: Conditional Events are used if the event should be triggered by a condition. (see BPMN spec pp.263-264)

constructs.name: Signal_Event
constructs.description: Signal Events are used if the event should be triggered by a Signal. (see BPMN spec p.272)

constructs.name: Cancel_Event
constructs.description: Cancel Events are used in the context of modeling Transaction Sub-Processes. (see BPMN spec pp.261-262)

constructs.name: EventDefinitionRef
constructs.description: Instead of defining EventDefinitions directly at the event element it is also possible to reference an EventDefinition defined elsewhere. (see BPMN spec p.235 and p.262)

constructs.name: Terminate_Event
constructs.description: Terminate Events are used to terminate the execution of the whole process. (see BPMN spec pp.272-273)

constructs.name: Compensation_Event
constructs.description: Compensation Events are used in the context of triggering or handling compensation. (see BPMN spec p.262)

constructs.name: Link_Event
constructs.description: A Link Event is a mechanism for connecting two sections of a Process. (see BPMN spec pp.266-269)

constructs.name: Multiple_Events
constructs.description: Multiple Events combine different event definitions. (see BPMN spec pp.270-272)

constructs.name: Escalation_Event
constructs.description: Escalation Events are used if the event should be triggered by an Escalation. (see BPMN spec pp.265-266)

groups.name: activities
groups.description: Activities can be Tasks, different kinds of SubProcesses, and CallActivities, and they model specific tasks in the real world.

constructs.name: LoopTask
constructs.description: The StandardLoopCharacteristics class defines looping behavior based on a boolean condition. The Activity will loop as long as the boolean condition is true. (see BPMN spec p.189)

constructs.name: ReceiveTask
constructs.description: A Receive Task is a simple Task that is designed to wait for a Message to arrive from an external Participant (relative to the Process). Once the Message has been received, the Task is completed. (see BPMN spec p.159)

constructs.name: AdHocSubProcess
constructs.description: An Ad-Hoc Sub-Process is a specialized type of Sub-Process that is a group of Activities that have no required sequence relationships. (see BPMN spec p.179)

constructs.name: Transaction
constructs.description: A Transaction is a specialized type of Sub-Process that will have a special behavior that is controlled through a transaction protocol. (see BPMN spec p.176)

constructs.name: MultiInstanceTask
constructs.description: MultiInstanceTasks allows for creation of a desired number of Activity instances. The instances can be defined to be executed in parallel or sequential. (see BPMN spec p.190)

constructs.name: SendTask
constructs.description: A Send Task is a simple Task that is designed to send a Message to an external Participant (relative to the Process). Once the Message has been sent, the Task is completed. (see BPMN spec p.157)

constructs.name: TokenCardinality
constructs.description: All activities can specify how much so called tokens are needed to start the execution/are created upon completion. (see BPMN spec pp.150-151)

constructs.name: CallActivity
constructs.description: A Call Activity identifies a point in the Process where a global Process or a Global Task is used. The Call Activity acts as a €wrapper€ for the invocation of a global Process or Global Task within the execution. (see BPMN spec p.182)

constructs.name: SubProcess
constructs.description: A Sub-Process is an Activity whose internal details have been modeled using Activities, Gateways, Events, and Sequence Flows. (see BPMN spec p.171)

groups.name: scopes
groups.description: Scopes provide the execution context of their enclosed activities.

constructs.name: PartnerLinks
constructs.description: The notion of <partnerLinks> is used to directly model peer-to-peer conversational partner relationships. (p. 36, BPEL)

constructs.name: EventHandlers
constructs.description: Each scope, including the process scope, can have a set of event handlers. These event handlers can run concurrently and are invoked when the corresponding event occurs. (p. 137, BPEL)

constructs.name: FaultHandlers
constructs.description: Fault handling in a business process can be thought of as a mode switch from the normal processing in a scope. Fault handling in WS-BPEL is designed to be treated as "reverse work," in that its aim is to undo the partial and unsuccessful work of a scope in which a fault has occurred. (p. 127, BPEL)

constructs.name: Scope-Attributes
constructs.description: All attributes of <scope> or <process>, being exitOnStandardFault and isolated

constructs.name: MessageExchanges
constructs.description: Manages message exchanges consisting of inbound message activities (IMA) and optional replies.

constructs.name: Compensation
constructs.description: The ability to declare compensation logic alongside forward-working logic is the underpinning of the application-controlled error-handling framework of WS-BPEL. (p. 118, BPEL)

constructs.name: Variables
constructs.description: Variables can be attached to <scope> or <process> elements.

constructs.name: CorrelationSets
constructs.description: Correlation can be used on every messaging activity and are defined on <scope> or <process>. They ensure that the messages are routed to the process instance where the correlation set matches.

constructs.name: TerminationHandlers
constructs.description: Termination handlers provide the ability for scopes to control the semantics of forced termination to some degree. (p. 136, BPEL)

groups.name: basic
groups.description: Basic activities are the basic building blocks of a BPEL process.

constructs.name: Rethrow
constructs.description: The <rethrow> activity is used in fault handlers to rethrow the fault they caught, i.e. the fault name and, where present, the fault data of the original fault. (p. 96, BPEL)

constructs.name: Invoke
constructs.description: The <invoke> activity is used to call Web Services offered by service providers. (p. 84, BPEL)

constructs.name: Validate
constructs.description: The <validate> activity can be used to ensure that values of variables are valid against their associated XML data definition, including XML Schema simple type, complex type, element definition and XML definitions of WSDL parts. (p. 48, BPEL)

constructs.name: ReceiveReply
constructs.description: The <reply> activity is used to send a response to a request previously accepted through an inbound message activity such as the <receive> activity. (p. 92, BPEL)

constructs.name: Throw
constructs.description: The <throw> activity is used when a business process needs to signal an internal fault explicitly. (p. 94, BPEL)

constructs.name: Receive
constructs.description: A <receive> is a blocking activity in that it will not complete until a matching message is received by the process instance. (p.91, BPEL)

constructs.name: Assign
constructs.description: Variable update occurs through the <assign> activity. (p. 94, BPEL)

constructs.name: Empty
constructs.description: An activity which does nothing.

constructs.name: Exit
constructs.description: The <exit> activity is used to immediately end the business process instance. (p. 96, BPEL)

constructs.name: Wait
constructs.description: The <wait> activity specifies a delay for a certain period of time or until a certain deadline is reached (p. 95, BPEL)

constructs.name: Variables
constructs.description: Groups together several features regarding initialization of variables.

groups.name: structured
groups.description: Structured activities compose basic activities into a control-flow graph.

constructs.name: ForEach
constructs.description: The <forEach> activity will execute its contained <scope> activity exactly N+1 times where N equals the <finalCounterValue> minus the <startCounterValue>. (p. 112, BPEL)

constructs.name: RepeatUntil
constructs.description: The <repeatUntil> activity provides for repeated execution of a contained activity. The contained activity is executed until the given Boolean <condition> becomes true. (p. 100, BPEL)

constructs.name: If
constructs.description: The <if> activity provides conditional behavior. The activity consists of an ordered list of one or more conditional branches defined by the <if> and optional <elseif> elements, followed by an optional <else> element. (p. 99, BPEL)

constructs.name: Flow
constructs.description: The <flow> activity provides concurrency and synchronization. (p. 102, BPEL)

constructs.name: Sequence
constructs.description: A <sequence> activity contains one or more activities that are performed sequentially, in the lexical order in which they appear within the <sequence> element. (p. 98, BPEL)

constructs.name: Pick
constructs.description: The <pick> activity waits for the occurrence of exactly one event from a set of events, then executes the activity associated with that event. After an event has been selected, the other events are no longer accepted by that <pick>. (p. 100, BPEL)

constructs.name: While
constructs.description: The <while> activity provides for repeated execution of a contained activity. The contained activity is executed as long as the Boolean <condition> evaluates to true at the beginning of each iteration. (p. 99, BPEL)
